intro: Ocimum selloi var. genuinum, commonly known as the Ethiopian basil, is a perennial herb native to Ethiopia. It belongs to the Lamiaceae family, characterized by its aromatic leaves and square stems. The plant typically grows to a height of 30–60 cm, featuring opposite, ovate to lanceolate leaves with a fragrant, spicy scent. Its flowers are small, clustered in whorls, and range in color from white to pale purple. This variety is valued for its culinary and medicinal uses, particularly in traditional Ethiopian cuisine and herbal remedies.
